responses.content: GB200 NVLink72 demand remains extraordinary, GB300 production ramped quickly with 1,000 racks per week, and Blackwell Ultra is generating tens of billions while reasoning AI continues to flood token demand.

Rubin remains on schedule for next year, and every hyperscaler/enterprise is building AI factories with NVLink 72 plus Spectrum-XGS; Rubin will slot into the same chassis, keeping our annual cadence intact.
We continue to advocate for licenses, but the current policy kept H20 out of China; we can ship $2–5B of H20 if more licenses arrive, yet the quarter assumed zero China shipments.

Networking hit $7.3B thanks to Spectrum-X, Spectrum-XGS, InfiniBand XDR, NVLink switches, NVLink Fusion, and Quantum-X photonics—every gigawatt AI factory needs the low-latency fabric we keep building.
Revenue beat at $46.7B, Data Center grew 56% year-over-year, and we released $180M of H20 reserves alongside $650M of unrestricted H20 sales while still returning $10B to shareholders.
Q3 outlook assumes no H20 to China, GAAP/non-GAAP gross margins ~73.3%/73.5%, OpEx up ~8% sequentially, and full-year operating expense growth still in the high-30s range.
Cash from operations exceeded $15B; we returned $10B and the Board added $60B to the repurchase authorization while CapEx funds Blackwell/GB300 ramp plus NVLink/Spectrum-X infrastructure.

questions: With wafer-to-rack lead times near 12 months and Rubin on track for the second half, how do you see growth into 2026 split between networking and data center?
What needs to happen on licenses for the $2–5B of China H20 demand, and do you worry ASIC-focused competitors taking share from your full-stack platform?
You cited a $3–4 trillion AI infrastructure opportunity—does that mean you expect to capture over 35% of the compute stack, and are power constraints the main limiter?
What are the prospects for reopening China with H20 or Blackwell once licenses arrive, and how important is that market to your long-term leadership?
How should we think about Spectrum-XGS sizing within Ethernet and data center interconnect spending as the AI super factory footprint grows?
Of the $7B sequential growth, how should we apportion it across Blackwell, Hopper/H20, and networking given that Hopper still shipped and Blackwell remained the lion’s share?
Is the outlook assuming zero China H20, and what conditions would need to change for you to resume those shipments?

metadata.source: NVIDIA FY 2026 Q2 earnings call transcript
